{{Constitutions of Poland}} '''April Novelization''' ({{lang-pl|Nowela kwietniowa}}) refers to the changes ([[constitutional amendment]]s) to the 1952 [[Constitution of the People's Republic of Poland]], agreed in April 1989, in the aftermath of the [[Polish Round Table Agreement]].
Among key changes were: *restoration of the [[Senate of Poland]] and the post of the [[president of Poland]] (the latter annulling the power of the [[Polish United Workers' Party]] [[general secretary]]) *introduction of the [[National Council of the Judiciary]] (''Krajowa Rada Sądownictwa'') *changes to the electoral legislation, in order to make elections more free and fair *powers of the [[Sejm]] were adjusted
The 1952 constitution would be even further reformed by the [[December Novelization]] and [[Small Constitution of 1992]], and finally replaced in 1997 by a completely new current [[Constitution of Poland]].
==External links== *[http://isap.sejm.gov.pl/DetailsServlet?id=WDU19890190101 Law from 7 April 1989 "On amendments to the Constitution of the People's Republic of Poland]{{Pl icon}} (April Novelization) *[http://isap.sejm.gov.pl/DetailsServlet?id=WDU19890750444 Law from 29 December 1989 "On amendments to the Constitution of the People's Republic of Poland]{{Pl icon}} (the [[December Novelization]])

|Prior={{cite BAILII |litigants=Assange v The Swedish Judicial Authority|court=EWHC |division=Admin |year=2011 |num=2849 |para= |eucase= |parallelcite= |courtname= |juimris=}} |Procedural= ''The judicial authority in Sweden v Julian Paul Assange'' (Westminster Magistrates)
|Holding= A European Arrest Warrant issued by a public prosecutor is a valid Part 1 warrant issued by a judicial authority within the meaning of section 2(2) and 66 of the Extradition Act 2003. |Majority= Phillips joined by Brown, Dyson, Kerr, and Walker |Dissent= Hale and Mance |Area of Law= [[Extradition]]
|Applied= |Reversed previous case= |Distinguished previous case= |Reversed= |Distinguished= |Followed= |ECtHR= |ECJ= }}
'''''Julian Assange v Swedish Prosecution Authority''''' were the set of legal proceedings in the [[United Kingdom]] concerning the requested extradition of [[Julian Assange]] to [[Sweden]] to further a 'preliminary investigation'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2010/09/sweden-reopens-possible-rape-case-against-wikileaks-founder-julian-assange/1|title=Sweden reopens rape investigation against Wikileaks founder Julian Assange|publisher=[[USA Today]]|author=Douglas Stanglin|date=September 2010}}</ref> into accusations of his having committed sexual offences. The proceedings began in 2012 and on 12 August 2015, Swedish prosecutors announced that they would drop their investigation into three of the allegations against Assange, because of the expiration of the statute of limitations. The investigation into the allegation of rape, as of 19 May 2017, has been dropped by Swedish authorities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.democracynow.org/2017/5/19/human_rights_lawyer_sweden_dropping_investigation|title=Human Rights Lawyer: Sweden Dropping Investigation of WikiLeaks' Assange is "Long Overdue Decision"|last=Avila|first=Renata|date=19 May 2017|work=[[Democracy Now!]]|access-date=2017-05-22}}</ref><ref name="emergence">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/05/19/sweden-drops-julian-assange-rape-investigation/|title=Julian Assange emerges on embassy balcony to say he will not 'forgive or forget' as Swedish rape investigation is dropped|first1=James|last1=Rothwell|first2=Victoria|last2=Ward|first3=Helen|last3=Nianias|publisher=The Telegraph|date=2017-05-19|accessdate=2017-07-05}}</ref> A disputed issue over the course of the legal proceedings was the claimed fear that Assange could ultimately be extradited to [[United States|United States of America]] should he be sent to Sweden. The [[United Nations]] [[Working Group on Arbitrary Detention]] has stated that "the various forms of deprivation of liberty to which Julian Assange has been subjected constitute a form of arbitrary detention", calling for the case to be closed and Assange to be allowed to walk free.<ref>https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/nov/30/un-panel-upholds-decision-julian-assanges-detainme/</ref><ref>https://www.firstpost.com/world/britain-sweden-should-accept-ruling-on-julian-assange-un-high-commissioner-for-human-rights-2618960.html</ref>
==Swedish investigation==
===Complaints and initial investigation=== On 20 August 2010, two women, a 26-year-old living in [[Enköping]] and a 31-year-old living in [[Stockholm]],<ref name=Cody>{{cite news |title=WikiLeaks stalled by Swedish inquiry into allegations of rape by founder Assange |first=Edward |last=Cody |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/08/AR2010090803240_pf.html |work=The Washington Post |date=9 September 2010 |accessdate=9 September 2010}}</ref><ref name=india>{{cite news |title=Sex accusers boasted about their 'conquest' of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-12-09/us/28247531_1_wikileaks-founder-julian-assange-swedish-women-condom |work=The Times of India |date=9 December 2009 |accessdate=10 December 2010}}</ref> jointly went to the [[Swedish police]] not seeking to bring charges against Assange but in order to track him down and persuade him to be tested for sexually transmitted diseases after their separate sexual encounters with him.<ref name=std>{{cite news|last=Hosenball |first=Mark |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/12/07/us-wikileaks-assange-charges-idUSTRE6B669H20101207 |title=Special Report: STD fears sparked case against WikiLeaks boss |publisher=Reuters |date= 7 December 2010|accessdate=2011-03-29}}</ref> The police told them that they could not simply tell Assange to take a test, but that their statements would be passed to the prosecutor.<ref name="10days" /> Later that day, the duty prosecutor ordered the arrest of Julian Assange on the suspicion of rape and molestation.<ref name="Swedish Prosecution Authority"/>
The next day, the case was transferred to Chefsåklagare (Chief Public Prosecutor) Eva Finné. In answer to questions surrounding the incidents, the following day, Finné declared, "I don't think there is reason to suspect that he has committed rape". However, Karin Rosander from the [[Swedish Prosecution Authority]], said Assange remained suspected of molestation. Police gave no further comment at the time, but continued the investigation.<ref name=basis>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11049316|title=Swedish rape warrant for Wikileaks' Assange cancelled|publisher=BBC News | date=21 August 2010}}</ref>
After learning of the investigation, Assange said, "The charges are without basis and their issue at this moment is deeply disturbing".<ref name=Davies>{{cite news |title=WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange denies rape allegations |first=Caroline |last=Davies |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/aug/22/wikileaks-julian-assange-denies-rape-allegations |newspaper=The Guardian |date=22 August 2010 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref>
The preliminary investigation concerning suspected rape was discontinued by Finné on 25 August,<ref name="Swedish Prosecution Authority">{{cite web|title=Chronology|url=http://www.aklagare.se/In-English/Media/The-Assange-Matter/The-Assange-Matter|publisher=Swedish Prosecution Authority|accessdate=28 November 2012}}</ref> but two days later [[Claes Borgström]], the attorney representing the two women, requested a review of the prosecutor's decision to terminate part of the investigation.<ref name="Swedish Prosecution Authority"/><ref name="BBC News Europe">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11949341|title=Timeline: sexual allegations against Assange in Sweden | publisher=BBC News | date=16 August 2012}}</ref>
On 30 August, Assange was questioned by the Stockholm police regarding the allegations of sexual molestation.<ref name=questioned>{{cite news |title=WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange questioned by police |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/aug/31/wikileaks-julian-assange-questioned |work=The Guardian |date=31 August 2010 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref> He denied the allegations, saying he had consensual sexual encounters with the two women.<ref name="Davies"/><ref name=GuardCharges>{{cite news |title=WikiLeaks: Interpol issues wanted notice for Julian Assange |first1=David |last1=Leigh |first2=Luke |last2=Harding |first3=Afua |last3=Hirsch |first4=Ewen |last4=MacAskill |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/nov/30/interpol-wanted-notice-julian-assange |work=The Guardian |date=30 November 2010 |accessdate=1 December 2010}}</ref><ref name=timeline>{{cite news |title=Assange charges: Consensual sex or rape? |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40551118/ns/us_news-wikileaks_in_security/ |publisher=MSNBC|date=8 December 2010 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref>
=== Investigation reinstated === On 1 September 2010, Överåklagare (Director of Public Prosecution) [[Marianne Ny]] decided to resume the preliminary investigation concerning all of the original allegations. On 18 August 2010, Assange had applied for a work and residence permit in Sweden.<ref name=BBCtimeline/><ref name=TheLocalSV>{{cite news|title=Assange denied Swedish residence permit|url=http://www.thelocal.se/29684/20101018/|accessdate=5 March 2011|newspaper=The Local - Sweden|date=18 October 2010}}</ref> On 18 October 2010, his request was denied.<ref name=BBCtimeline>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11949341 |title=Timeline: sexual allegations against Assange in Sweden |publisher=BBC News|date=2010-12-16 |accessdate=2011-03-29}}</ref><ref name=TheLocalSV/><ref name=RundleTImeline>{{cite web|url=http://www.crikey.com.au/2010/12/13/rundle-timeline-of-assanges-visit-to-sweden-and-events-that-followed/ |title=Rundle: timeline of Assange’s visit to Sweden and events that followed |publisher=Crikey |accessdate=2011-03-29}}</ref> He left Sweden on 27 September 2010. According to one source his departure was with the permission of the Swedish authorities.<ref name=guardiansms>{{cite news|last=Esther Addley|title=Julian Assange's accusers sent texts discussing revenge, court hears|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/feb/08/julian-assange-extradition-hearing-texts|accessdate=2011-03-12|newspaper=Guardian|date=8 February 2011}}</ref> Another source claims that the Swedish authorities notified Assange's lawyer of his imminent arrest on that same day.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sweden Questions Assange's Departure|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704422204576129703079523420?mod=wsj_share_tweet | work=The Wall Street Journal | first=Jeanne|last=Whalen|date=8 February 2011}}</ref>
=== Arrest warrant === On 18 November 2010, Marianne Ny ordered the detention of Julian Assange on suspicion of rape, three cases of sexual molestation and unlawful coercion. The Stockholm District Court acceded to the order and issued a European Arrest Warrant to execute it.<ref name="Swedish Prosecution Authority"/> The warrant was appealed to the [[Svea Court of Appeal]] which upheld its issuance, but lowered it to suspicion of rape of a lesser degree, unlawful coercion and two cases of sexual molestation rather than three.<ref name="Press Release">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11803703 | work=BBC News | title=Wikileaks' Assange faces international arrest warrant | date=20 November 2010}}</ref><ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15549985 | work=BBC News | title=Wikileaks' Julian Assange loses extradition appeal | date=2 November 2011}}</ref> The warrant was also appealed to the [[Supreme Court of Sweden]], which decided not to hear the case.<ref name="Supreme Court Protocoll">{{cite web|url=http://undermattan.com/files/2012/08/ASSANGE-HD-Tillst%C3%A5ndspr%C3%B6vning-2010.pdf |title=Supreme Court Protocoll|publisher=undermattan.com |accessdate=2012-11-28}}</ref> At this time Assange had been living in the United Kingdom for 1–2 months. An [[extradition]] hearing took place in an English court in February 2011 to consider an application by Swedish authorities for the extradition of Assange to Sweden. The outcome of the hearing was announced on 24 February 2011, when the extradition warrant was upheld. Assange appealed to the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]]. On 2 November 2011, the court upheld the extradition decision and rejected all four grounds for the appeal as presented by Assange's legal representatives. £19,000 costs was also awarded against Assange. On 5 December 2011, Assange was refused permission by the High Court to appeal to the [[Supreme Court of the United Kingdom|Supreme Court]]. The High Court certified that his case raised a point of law of general public importance. The Supreme Court subsequently granted permission to appeal,<ref name="supreme">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16027942|title=Julian Assange wins right to pursue extradition fight |publisher=The BBC|date=5 December 2011|accessdate=13 December 2011}}</ref> and heard the appeal on 1 and 2 February 2012.<ref name=supremebbc>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16822257 Assange extradition case is heard by Supreme Court]</ref> The court reserved its judgment and dismissed the appeal on 30 May 2012.<ref name=loses/> Assange has said the investigation is "without basis". He remained on conditional [[Bail#England and Wales|bail]] in the United Kingdom.<ref name=questioned /><ref name=abcnews>{{cite news |title=Tell-All on WikiLeaks' Assange Coming out in March |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=12952197 |newspaper=ABC News |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref><ref name=BBCa>{{cite news |title=Wikileaks' Assange appeals over Sweden arrest warrant |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11880965 |newspaper=BBC News |date=1 December 2010 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref> On 19 June 2012, Assange sought refuge at [[Ecuador's Embassy in London]] and was granted temporary asylum. On 16 August 2012, he was granted full asylum by the Ecuadorian government but has been unable to leave the embassy without being arrested.
=== Review of detention order === On the 24 June 2014, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported<ref name=guardian20140624>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jun/24/julian-assange-legal-bid-sweden-rape-case|title=Julian Assange makes fresh bid to break deadlock in Swedish rape case|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=24 June 2014}}</ref> that Assange's lawyers filed a request to [[Stockholm District Court]] to dismiss his detention,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://justice4assange.com/Assange-files-case-to-dismiss.html|title=Assange files case to dismiss Swedish warrant|publisher=Justice for Assange|quote=On Tuesday 24th of June at 1pm CET, Julian Assange’s lawyers filed a request to Stockholm District Court to rescind the decision to detain him without charge.}}</ref> based on an update to Sweden's code of judicial procedure (1 June 2014) to conform with EU law including a new provision that those arrested or detained have the right to be made aware of "facts forming the basis for the decision to arrest".
On 16 July 2014, the Stockholm District Court reviewed the detention order on request by Assange. During the course of the proceedings, Assange's defence lawyers said that the prosecutors have a "duty" to advance the case, and that they had shown "passivity" in refusing to go to London to interview Assange.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jul/16/julian-assange-lawyers-appeal-ruling-uphold-arrest-warrant/ | title=Julian Assange's lawyers will appeal against ruling to uphold arrest warrant | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=17 July 2014 | accessdate=17 July 2014 |author=Crouch, David}}</ref> After hearing evidence, the district court concluded that there was probable cause to suspect Assange of committing the alleged crimes, and that the detention order should remain in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://domstol.se/Om-Sveriges-Domstolar/Sveriges-Domstolars-pressrum/Nyheter-och-pressmeddelanden/Beslut-i-fraga-om-haktning-i-utevaro--Decision-concering-a-detention-order/ |title=Decision concerning a detention order|publisher=domstol.se |accessdate=2014-07-16}}</ref>
In response, Assange's Swedish legal team stated to [[Radio Sweden]]: "We still think we have very good legal arguments to get this decision overruled, so we are confident in the result of the appeal. We think the court of appeal can make another decision on the same arguments as the district court."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2054&artikel=5916481|title=Assange team confident of Appeal Court win|date=17 July 2014}}</ref> Ecuador immediately issued a statement: "The Ecuadorian Government reaffirms its offer of judicial cooperation to the Kingdom of Sweden, to reach a prompt solution to the case. In this sense Ecuador keeps its invitation to judicial officers visit the London Embassy so that Julian Assange can be interviewed or via videoconference. Both possibilities are explicitly referred in the current procedural legislation in Sweden and the European Union."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cancilleria.gob.ec/ecuador-reaffirms-its-commitment-in-defense-of-human-rights-freedom-and-the-life-of-julian-assange/?lang=en|title=Ecuador reaffirms its commitment in defense of human rights, freedom and the life of Julian Assange|date=16 July 2014}}</ref>
On 20 November 2014, the Swedish Court of Appeal refused Assange's appeal, upholding the 2010 detention order, though at the same time issuing a statement criticising the prosecution for not having done more to advance the case by proceeding with an interrogation of Assange.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-30129453|title= Swedish court upholds Assange order |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=20 November 2014 |website=BBC News | accessdate=20 November 2014}}</ref>
=== Inquiry into three of the allegations dropped === On 12 August 2015, Swedish prosecutors announced that, as the [[statute of limitations]] for the less serious allegations had run out, and they had not succeeded in interviewing Assange, they would end part of their preliminary investigation. After 18 August 2015, Assange could no longer be charged for any of the three less serious charges. However, the preliminary investigation into the more serious allegation remained open as the statute of limitations for this charge was not expected to expire until 2020.<ref name="bbcdrop">{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-33894757 |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=12 August 2015 |title=Assange Assault Inquiry to Be Dropped |last=Hawley |first=Caroline}}</ref> Swedish authorities interviewed Assange on this allegation in November 2016.<ref name="testimony" />
===Revocation of arrest warrant===
On 19 May 2017, the Swedish chief prosecutor applied to the Stockholm District Court to rescind the arrest warrant for Julian Assange,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-39973864|title=Julian Assange: Sweden drops rape investigation|last=|first=|date=19 May 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=20 May 2017|language=en-GB}}</ref> effectively ceasing their investigation against Julian Assange.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/may/19/swedish-prosecutors-drop-julian-assange-investigation|title=Swedish prosecutors drop Julian Assange rape investigation|last=Addley|first=Esther|date=19 May 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=20 May 2017|last2=Travis|first2=Alan|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> The case may be reinstated until the expiration of the statute of limitations. Additionally, Britain's arrest warrant pertaining to bail violations remains open.
==Extradition process==
===First instance proceedings===
====Detention and bail==== Assange presented himself to the [[Metropolitan Police]] on December 7, 2010, and was [[Remand (court procedure)|remanded]] to [[London]]'s [[Wandsworth Prison]].<ref name=Addley2>{{cite news |title=Q&A: Julian Assange allegations |first=Esther |last=Addley |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/dec/17/julian-assange-q-and-a |newspaper=The Guardian |date=17 December 2010 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref> On 16 December, he was [[Bail#England and Wales|granted bail]] with bail conditions of residence at [[Ellingham Hall, Norfolk]], and wearing of an [[Electronic tagging|electronic tag]]. Bail was set at [[£]]240,000 [[surety]] with a deposit of £200,000 ([[$]]312,700).<ref name=Local3>{{cite news |title=Extradition part of 'smear campaign': Assange |url=http://www.thelocal.se/30916/20101217/ |newspaper=The Local |date=17 December 2010 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref>
On release on bail, Assange said "I hope to continue my work and continue to protest my innocence in this matter,"<ref name=ThomsonReuters>{{cite news |title=WikiLeaks' Assange walks free on bail in London |first1=Isabel |last1=Coles |first2=Avril |last2=Ormsby |url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCAL3E6N80HH20101216 |publisher=Thomson Reuters |date=16 December 2010 |accessdate=16 December 2010}}</ref> and told the BBC, "This has been a very successful [[smear campaign]] and a very wrong one."<ref name=VancouverSun>{{cite news |title=WikiLeaks' Julian Assange says he is victim of smear campaign |first=Avril |last=Ormsby |url=https://vancouversun.com/news/WikiLeaks+Julian+Assange+says+victim+smear+campaign/3992455/story.html |newspaper=The Vancouver Sun |date=17 December 2010 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref> He claimed that the extradition proceedings to Sweden were "actually an attempt to get me into a jurisdiction which will then make it easier to extradite me to the US." Swedish prosecutors have denied the case has anything to do with WikiLeaks.<ref name=Local3 />
====Extradition hearing==== The extradition hearing took place on 7–8 and 11 February 2011 before the [[City of Westminster Magistrates' Court]] sitting at Belmarsh Magistrates' Court in London.<ref name=Sydney>{{cite news |title=Besieged Assange hires PR team |url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/besieged-assange-hires-pr-team-20110108-19j5f.html |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=8 January 2011 |accessdate=8 January 2011}}</ref><ref name=Addley3>{{cite news |title=WikiLeaks: Julian Assange 'faces execution or Guantánamo detention' |first=Esther |last=Addley |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jan/11/julian-assange-wikileaks-execution-gantanamo |newspaper=The Guardian |date=11 January 2011 |accessdate=13 January 2011}}</ref> Assange's lawyers at the extradition hearing were [[Geoffrey Robertson]] [[Queen's Counsel|QC]] and [[Mark Stephens (solicitor)|Mark Stephens]], human rights specialists, and the prosecution was represented by a team led by Clare Montgomery QC.<ref name=voanews>{{cite news |title=Lawyer: WikiLeaks Founder Cannot Get Fair Trial in Sweden |first= |last= |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/europe/Lawyer-WikiLeaks-Founder-Cannot-Get-Fair-Trial-in-Sweden-115938559.html |publisher=Voice of America |date=11 February 2011 |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> Arguments were presented as to whether the Swedish prosecutor had the authority to issue a European Arrest Warrant, the extradition was requested for prosecution or interrogation, the alleged crimes qualified as extradition crimes, there was an abuse of process, his human rights would be respected, and he would receive a fair trial if extradited to Sweden.
====Extradition decision==== The outcome of the hearing was announced on 24 February 2011, when the extradition warrant was upheld.<ref name=Dodd>{{cite news |title=Julian Assange extradition attempt an uphill struggle, says specialist |first=Vikram |last=Dodd |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/dec/08/julian-assange-extradition-attempt |newspaper=The Guardian |date=8 December 2010 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref><ref name=hearing1>{{cite news |title=Julian Assange extradition hearing – final day live updates |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/blog/2011/feb/11/julian-assange-extradition-hearing-live#block-18 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=8 February 2011 |accessdate=11 February 2011 |first=Simon |last=Jeffery}}</ref><ref name=refused>{{cite news |title=Wikileaks founder Julian Assange refused bail |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11937110 |newspaper=BBC News |date=8 December 2010 |accessdate=8 December 2010}}</ref> Senior District Judge Howard Riddle found against Assange on each of the main arguments against his extradition.<ref name=Coleman /> The judge said "as a matter of fact, and looking at all the circumstances in the round, this person (Mr Assange) passes the threshold of being an accused person and is wanted for prosecution."<ref name=Coleman /> Judge Riddle concluded: "I am satisfied that the specified offences are extradition offences."<ref name=Coleman>{{cite news |title=Wikileaks' Julian Assange handed 'resounding defeat' |first=Clive |last=Coleman |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12569462 |newspaper=BBC News |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=25 February 2011}}</ref>
Assange commented after the decision to extradite him, saying "It comes as no surprise but is nevertheless wrong. It comes as the result of a European arrest warrant system run amok."<ref name=Addley4>{{cite news |title=Julian Assange attacks 'rubber-stamp' warrant as he loses extradition battle |first1=Esther |last1=Addley |first2=Alexandra |last2=Topping |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/feb/24/julian-assange-extradition-sweden-verdict |newspaper=The Guardian |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=25 February 2011}}</ref>
===Appeal to the High Court=== On 2 March 2011, Assange's lawyers lodged an appeal with the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] challenging the decision to extradite him to Sweden.<ref name=ExtraApp1Guardian>{{cite news|last=Meikle|first=James|title=Julian Assange lodges extradition appeal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/mar/03/julian-assange-extradition-appeal?INTCMP=SRCH|accessdate=5 March 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=3 March 2011}}</ref> Assange remained on conditional bail.<ref name=ExtraApp1Guardian /><ref>{{cite news|last=Gordon, PA|first=Cathy|title=WikiLeaks' Assange appeals against UK extradition|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/03/us-britain-assange-appeal-idUSTRE7222LH20110303|accessdate=5 March 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=3 March 2011}}</ref> The appeal hearing took place on 12 and 13 July 2011 at the High Court in London. The judges' decision was reserved, and a written judgment was delivered on 2 November 2011, dismissing the appeal.<ref>{{Cite BAILII |litigants=Assange v. Swedish Prosecution Authority |year=2011 |court=EWHC |division=Admin |num=2849}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Assange case set for July|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/assange-case-set-for-july-2264136.html|accessdate=9 April 2011|newspaper=The Independent|date=7 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wikileaks' Julian Assange extradition decision deferred|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14139329 | work=BBC News | date=13 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/oct/28/julian-assange-extradition-judgment | work=The Guardian | first1=Robert | last1=Booth | first2=Esther | last2=Addley | title=Julian Assange extradition judgment due on Wednesday | date=28 October 2011}}</ref><ref name=HighCourtSummary>{{cite web|url=http://www.judiciary.gov.uk/Resources/JCO/Documents/Judgments/assange-summary.pdf |title=Assange v Swedish Prosecution Authority |publisher=Judiciary of England and Wales |date=2011-11-02 |accessdate=2017-07-05 |archivedate=2013-03-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130310021505/http://www.judiciary.gov.uk/Resources/JCO/Documents/Judgments/assange-summary.pdf |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
===Appeal to the Supreme Court=== The High Court refused permission to appeal to the [[Supreme Court of the United Kingdom|Supreme Court]], but this was granted by the Supreme Court itself, after the High Court certified that a point of law of general public importance was involved in its decision.
The point of law certified was whether the wording ''Judicial Authority'' in the [[2003 Extradition Act]] was to be interpreted as a “person who is competent to exercise judicial authority and that such competence requires impartiality and independence of both the executive and the parties” or if it “embraces a variety of bodies, some of which have the qualities of impartiality and independence …and some of which do not.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.supremecourt.uk/docs/UKSC_2011_0264_Judgment.pdf |title=Supreme court judgement |publisher=the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom |date=2012-05-30 |accessdate=2012-12-04}}</ref>
The Supreme Court heard the appeal on 1 and 2 February 2012.<ref name=supremebbc /> The court reserved its judgment,<ref name=supremeguardian>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/blog/2012/feb/02/julian-assange-extradition-appeal-at-supreme-court-day-two-live-blog | work=The Guardian | first=Paul | last=Owen | title=Julian Assange extradition appeal at supreme court - Thursday 2 February | date=2 February 2012}}</ref> and dismissed the appeal by a 5–2 majority on 30 May 2012.<ref name=loses>{{cite news |title=Julian Assange loses extradition appeal at Supreme Court |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18260914 |newspaper=BBC News |date=30 May 2012 |accessdate=30 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite BAILII |litigants=Assange v The Swedish Judicial Authority|court=UKSC |division= |year=2012 |num=22 |para= |eucase= |parallelcite= |courtname= |juris=}}</ref>
The court granted Assange two weeks to make an application to reopen the appeal after his counsel argued the judgments of the majority relied on an interpretation of the [[Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties]] that was not argued during the hearing.<ref>[http://www.supremecourt.uk/news/julian-assange-v-swedish-judicial-authority-judgment.html "Further statement – Julian Assange v Swedish Prosecution Authority,"] United Kingdom Supreme Court, 30 May 2012. Accessed 30 May 2012.</ref> The application was rejected on 14 June, thereby exhausting Assange's legal options in the United Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.supremecourt.uk/news/julian-assange-v-swedish-prosecution-authority.html Julian Assange v Swedish Prosecution Authority: Application to re-open appeal], Supreme Court, 14 June 2012. Accessed 18 March 2014.</ref>
Barring any appeal to the [[European Court of Human Rights]] in [[Strasbourg]], extradition was expected to take place over a ten-day period commencing on 28 June 2012.<ref>[http://zeenews.india.com/news/world/assange-loses-final-legal-bid-to-block-extradition-to-sweden_781869.html "Assange loses final legal bid to block extradition to Sweden,"] Zee News, 14 June 2012. Accessed 14 June 2012.</ref>
=== Ecuador asylum and bail forfeiture === {{wikinews|Assange seeks asylum in Ecuadorian embassy}} Since 19 June 2012, Assange has lived in the [[Embassy of Ecuador in London]], where he asked for and was granted [[political asylum]].<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/19/julian-assange-asylum-ecuador_n_1609725.html Reuters, 19.06.2012]</ref> Because Assange did not comply with his bail conditions, his supporters forfeited £93,500.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/08/julian-assange-supporters-ordered-forfeit-bail|title=Julian Assange supporters ordered to forfeit £93,500 bail money|last=Booth|first=Robert|date=2012-10-08|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-09-25}}</ref>
Assange’s lawyers invited the Swedish prosecutor four times to come and question him at the embassy, but the offer was refused.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/wikileaks-founder-julian-assange-to-release-files-on-50-countries-20140619-zse02.html|title=WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange to release files on 50 countries |first=Rick|last=Feneley|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=2014-06-19|accessdate=2017-07-05}}</ref> In March 2015, faced with the prospect of the Swedish statute of limitations expiring for some of the allegations, the prosecutor relented and agreed to question Assange in the Ecuadorean embassy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-31867829|title=Julian Assange case: Sweden U-turn on questioning|publisher=BBC|date=2015-03-13|accessdate=2017-07-05}}</ref> The UK agreed to the interview in May awaiting Ecuadorean approval.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/wikileaks/11681502/Why-is-Julian-Assange-still-inside-the-embassy-of-Ecuador.html|title=Why is Julian Assange still inside the embassy of Ecuador?|first=Harriet|last=Alexander|publisher=The Telegraph|date=2016-02-04|accessdate=2017-07-05}}</ref>
Assange said he would go to Sweden if provided with a diplomatic guarantee that he would not be turned over to the United States,<ref name=afp2102>{{cite news|last=AFP|title=WikiLeaks founder wants guarantee he won't be sent to US|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5juNu7AD08LPbrqXibOf5VLiZ_5GA|accessdate=16 August 2012|newspaper=Agence France-Presse|date=24 June 2012}}</ref> to which the Swedish foreign ministry stated that Sweden's legislation does not allow any judicial decision like extradition to be predetermined.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/sep/28/ecuador-julian-assange-embassy-wikileaks Guardian, September 2012]</ref> However, the Swedish government is free to reject extradition requests from non-EU countries, independent of any court decision.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.government.se/government-of-sweden/ministry-of-justice/international-judicial-co-operation/extradition-for-criminal-offences/ | title = Extradition for Criminal Offences | date = April 13, 2015 | publisher = The Government Offices of Sweden | access-date= 2015-06-22 | quote = The Government can, however, refuse extradition even if the Supreme Court has not declared against extradition, as the law states that if certain conditions are fulfilled, a person "may" be extradited - not "shall" be extradited. }}</ref>
=== Accusations === Assange was arrested in his absence and wanted for questioning in relation to accusations against him of rape and sexual molestation. This was the first step in the criminal prosecution procedure in Sweden, and only after the questioning would the prosecution authority be able to formally indict him.<ref name=10days>{{cite news|last=Nick Davies|title=10 days in Sweden: the full allegations against Julian Assange|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/dec/17/julian-assange-sweden|accessdate=2011-03-11|newspaper=Guardian|date=17 December 2010}}</ref>
=== l'Espresso document publication === On 20 October 2015, a new batch of documents resulting from a FOIA request to the Swedish authorities filed by the Italian news magazine [[l'Espresso]] was published online.<ref>[http://espresso.repubblica.it/internazionale/2015/10/16/news/five-years-confined-new-foia-documents-shed-light-on-the-julian-assange-case-1.235129?ref=twhe Five years confined: New Foia documents shed light on the Julian Assange case], 20 October 2015</ref> They contain records of correspondence between the [[Swedish Prosecution Authority]] and the [[Crown Prosecution Service]]. A CPS lawyer wrote in an email to Marianne Ny that "it would not be prudent for the Swedish authorities to try to interview the defendant in the [[UK]]... He would of course have no obligation under English law to answer any questions put to him.... any attempt to interview under strict Swedish law would invariably be fraught with problems." Referring to the case itself, he wrote, "It is simply amazing how much work this is generating... Do not think that the case is being dealt with as just another extradition request." Assange's legal team stated that, following these revelations, they would probably challenge the extradition request in court again.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/oct/19/julian-assange-lawyers-may-launch-new-appeal-emails?CMP=twt_gu Julian Assange lawyers may launch new appeal against extradition in light of CPS emails], 20 October 2015</ref>
=== Decision to interview Assange in London === In March 2015, Marianne Ny indicated that she would allow Assange to be interviewed in London, and that the interview would be conducted by a deputy prosecutor, Ingrid Isgren, as well as a police investigator.<ref name=Isgren>{{cite news|last=David Crouch|title=Julian Assange to be questioned by Swedish prosecutors in London|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/mar/13/julian-assange-wikileaks-swedish-prosecutors-london-interview|accessdate=2011-03-17|newspaper=Guardian|date=13 March 2015}}</ref> In December 2015, Ecuador stated that it had reached a deal with Sweden which would allow him to be interviewed in the Embassy.<ref name=dec2015>{{cite news|last=Jessica Elgot|title=Julian Assange may face Swedish interrogation within days |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/dec/12/julian-assange-may-face-swedish-interrogation-within-days|accessdate=2015-12-14|newspaper=Guardian|date=12 December 2015}}</ref> In September 2016, Ecuador set a date for Assange's interview over the rape allegation. The date was 17 October 2016. It was established that the interview would be conducted by an Ecuadorian prosecutor, with Isgren and a police officer present.<ref name=interview>{{cite news|last=Reuters|title=Date set for questioning of Julian Assange over rape allegation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/sep/14/date-set-questioning-julian-assange-rape-allegation|accessdate=2016-10-16|newspaper=Guardian|date=14 September 2015}}</ref> The interview was subsequently postponed until 14 November 2016, "to ensure the presence of Mr Assange’s attorneys," according to a spokesman for Assange’s legal team.<ref name=interviewpostponed>{{cite news|last=Esther Addley|title=Date set for questioning of Julian Assange over rape allegation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2016/oct/12/questioning-of-julian-assange-by-swedish-authorities-postponed|accessdate=2016-10-17|newspaper=Guardian|date=12 October 2015}}</ref> According to Assange's lawyer, the "shape" of the questions was still being discussed a week before the scheduled interview.<ref>{{cite news|title=Julian Assange to be questioned by Ecuador over rape allegation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/nov/07/julian-assange-to-be-questioned-by-ecuador-over-allegation|accessdate=9 November 2016|work=Guardian|date=7 November 2016}}</ref> Assange released his testimony to the public on 7 December.<ref name="testimony">{{cite news|title=Assange releases testimony from London questioning, says he is innocent|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ecuador-sweden-assange-idUSKBN13W20O?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews|accessdate=8 December 2016|agency=Reuters|date=7 December 2016}}</ref> In his statement, Assange says that his Swedish lawyer was not actually permitted to be present during the interview, among many other complaints concerning the length and irregularities of the process and events leading up to it.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Assange|first1=Julian|title=14/15 NOVEMBER 2016 QUESTIONING AT THE ECUADORIAN EMBASSY|url=https://justice4assange.com/IMG/html/assange-statement-2016.html|website=Justice4assange.com|accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref>
=== Opinion of arbitrary detention by UN Working Group and move to lift European arrest warrant=== On 5 February 2016, it was announced by the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] that the [[Working Group on Arbitrary Detention]] had found that Assange is effectively being held in [[arbitrary detention]] by the UK and Swedish governments in a [[binding precedent|legally-binding]] [[legal opinion|opinion]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Julian Assange arbitrarily detained by Sweden and the UK|url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=17013&LangID=E|accessdate=7 February 2016|publisher=Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights}}</ref> High Commissioner [[Zeid Ra'ad al Hussein]] reaffirmed later the same month that the opinion is based on binding [[international law]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Britain, Sweden should accept Assange ruling: UN rights chief|url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/swedish-prosecutor-vows-assange-london-105517466.html|accessdate=7 April 2017|agency=AFP News|publisher=Yahoo! News|date=9 February 2016}}</ref> Immediately following the opinion's publication, Assange's lawyers asked the Stockholm District Court to lift the European arrest warrant.<ref>{{cite news|title=Assange lawyers request overturn of arrest warrant.|url=http://www.newsmax.com/World/Europe/EU-Sweden-Ecuador-Assange/2016/02/22/id/715537/|accessdate=16 April 2016|publisher=Newsmax.com|date=22 February 2016|ref=http://www.newsmax.com/World/Europe/EU-Sweden-Ecuador-Assange/2016/02/22/id/715537/}}</ref> On 14 April, the Swedish prosecution authorities responded saying the warrant should be upheld.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dickson|first1=Daniel|title=Swedish prosecutors argue for upholding Assange arrest warrant.|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ecuador-sweden-assange-prosecutor-idUSKCN0XB0NU|accessdate=16 April 2016|publisher=Reuters.com|date=14 April 2016}}</ref> The Svea Court of Appeal decided to uphold the warrant on 16 September.<ref>{{cite news|title=Swedish appeals court upholds Assange detention order|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/swedish-appeals-court-upholds-assange-detention-order-160916092325122.html|accessdate=17 September 2016|publisher=al-Jazeera|date=16 September 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/julian-assanges-arrest-warrant-rape-case-upheld-sweden-court-n649296 " Julian Assange's Arrest Warrant in Rape Case Upheld by Swedish Court"]''NBC News'', 16 September 2016, Accessed 16 September 2016.</ref> After being asked by the British to review the case, the Working Group on Arbitrary Detention formally declined to do so in late November, saying that there was not enough new information provided to warrant such a review.<ref>{{cite news|title=UN panel: WikiLeaks' Assange a victim of arbitrary detention|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/World/2016/Nov-30/383544-un-panel-wikileaks-assange-a-victim-of-arbitrary-detention.ashx|accessdate=1 December 2016|work=The Daily Star (Lebanon)|agency=Associated Press|date=30 November 2016}}</ref>
=== Offers to Obama Administration ===
Assange and his supporters have expressed concerns that upon his return to Sweden, Assange may be extradited to the United States to face charges related to his professional work, since Wikileaks has been under investigation in the US since at least 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=Edward Snowden and others urge Trump to drop case against Assange|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/may/15/edward-snowden-assange-wikileaks-open-letter?CMP=twt_gu|accessdate=17 May 2017|work=The Guardian|date=15 May 2017}}</ref> On 13 January 2017, Wikileaks announced that Assange would agree to extradition to the United States if the [[Obama administration]] granted clemency to [[Chelsea Manning]] though he claimed the charges that might be pressed against him there had no merit.<ref>{{cite news|last=Firozi|first=Paulina|title=Assange agrees to be extradited if Obama grants clemency for Manning|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/news/314139-assange-agrees-to-be-extradited-to-us-if-obama-grants-clemency-for-chelsea|accessdate=13 January 2017|publisher=''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]''|date=13 January 2017}}</ref> The offer followed one made via Assange's attorney in September 2016 that an extradition waiver would be made conditional on a pardon for Manning.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2016/09/15/politics/julian-assange-wikileaks-chelsea-manning/ WikiLeaks' Julian Assange fails to overturn arrest warrant again], ''[[CNN]], Wesley Bruer & James Masters, September 16, 2016. Retrieved 18 January 2017.</ref> Chelsea Manning's sentence was commuted on Obama's last day in office but Assange's lawyers stated that the 120 day delay in her release did not meet the conditions of their offer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/julian-assange-chelsea-manning-barack-obama-hand-in-embassy-arrest-extradition-us-a7533911.html|title=Julian Assange will not hand himself in because Chelsea Manning's release won't happen immediately, lawyer says|first=Andrew|last=Griffin|publisher=The Independent|date=2017-01-18|accessdate=2017-07-05}}</ref> As of May 2017, the United Kingdom is refusing to deny rumours that it has received extradition requests from the United States.<ref name="emergence" />
=== Statements made by Trump Administration ===
Two weeks before the Swedish arrest warrant for Assange was dropped, one of his lawyers, Per Samuelson, reiterated his opposition to it saying "With the Supreme Court's own reasoning, his detention should now be rescinded because we can now prove that the U.S. is hunting Julian Assange."<ref>{{cite news|title=Assange lawyer asks Swedish court to tear up detention order|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ecuador-sweden-assange-idUSKBN17Z0P2|accessdate=5 May 2017|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=3 May 2017}}</ref> This followed public statements{{specify|reason=It would be nice to know what the statements were, or even to have a general summary of the content|date=January 2018}} made by American President [[Donald Trump]], [[CIA]] Director [[Mike Pompeo]], and Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]] as to the appropriateness of charging Assange in the U.S. with crimes related to WikiLeaks{{fact|date=January 2018}}.

{{Insolvency}} The Enterprise Bankruptcy Law of the [[China|People's Republic of China]] (trial Implementation) was first passed in 1986. On 1 June 2007, the new Enterprise Bankruptcy Law of the PRC came into force. It contains 136 articles, almost 100 more than the 1986 law it replaced, and consequently it is thought to be more complete legally.
The Enterprise Bankruptcy Law of the PRC was adopted in August 27, 2006, and became effective since June 1, 2007.
==Contents==
Chapter 1 General Provisions Chapter 2 Application and Acceptance Section 1 Application Section 2 Acceptance Chapter 3 Administrator Chapter 4 Debtor's Property Chapter 5 Expenses for Bankruptcy Proceedings and Debts of Common Benefits Chapter 6 Declaration of Credits Chapter 7 Creditors' Meeting Section 1 General Provisions Section 2 Creditors' Committee Chapter 8 Reorganization Section 1 Application for and Period of Reorganization Section 2 Preparation and Approval of Reorganization Plan Section 3 Execution of Reorganization Plan Chapter 9 Composition Chapter 10 Bankruptcy Liquidation Section 1 Declaration of Bankruptcy Section 2 Appraisal and Distribution Section 3 Termination of Bankruptcy Proceedings Chapter 11 Legal Liability Chapter 12 Supplementary Provisions
The Enterprise Bankruptcy Law of the PRC 2007 applies only to the mainland of China. Due to the "One Country, Two Systems" policy of the PRC, different laws and regulations regarding to bankruptcy apply in [[Hong Kong]] and [[Macau]].

The '''Building and Construction Authority''' ([[Abbreviation]]: '''BCA'''; {{zh|c=建设局}}) is a [[Statutory boards of the Singapore Government|statutory board]] under the [[Ministry of National Development (Singapore)|Ministry of National Development]] of the [[Singapore Government]]. It was established on 1 April 1999 through the merger of the Construction Industry Development Board and the Building Control Division of the former Public Works Department.<ref>{{cite book|title=Building Up. The Inaugural Annual Report 2000 of the Building and Construction Authority|year=2000|publisher=Building and Construction Authority}}</ref>
The primary role of BCA is to develop and regulate Singapore's building and construction industry.<ref>{{cite web|title=About BCA|url=http://www.bca.gov.sg/AboutUs/about_bca.html|publisher=Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=24 November 2011}}</ref>
== Building safety == BCA ensures that buildings in Singapore are designed, constructed and maintained to high standards of safety through its building regulatory system.
In October 2004, BCA issued a window retrofitting order, requiring aluminium rivets fitted on casement windows to be replaced with stainless steel rivets. Since the order came into force, BCA and the [[Housing Development Board]] (HDB) have been urging property owners and tenants to practise window safety through a public campaign. Every year, 6 June and 12 December have been designated as “Window Safety Days”, where property owners and tenants are encouraged to check their windows at least once every six months.<ref>{{cite web|title=Window Maintenance|url=http://www.bca.gov.sg/Windows_safety/windows_maintenance.html|publisher=Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=12 December 2011}}</ref>
BCA is also the lead agency in Singapore in regulating amusement rides to protect public safety. In July 2011, a new regulatory framework was introduced to protect the safety of ride-goers in Singapore.<ref>{{cite news|title=New regulations for amusement rides starting July|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/AsiaOne+News/Singapore/Story/A1Story20110624-285861.html|accessdate=24 November 2011|newspaper=AsiaOne|date=24 June 2011}}</ref>
== Sustainability == BCA actively promotes the use of green building technologies and designs through its Green Building Masterplan and various initiatives. Under the second Green Building Masterplan which was launched in 2009, BCA seeks to achieve the national target of greening at least 80% of the buildings in Singapore by 2030.<ref>{{cite web|title=2nd Green Building Masterplan|url=http://www.bca.gov.sg/GreenMark/others/gbmp2.pdf|publisher=Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=8 December 2011}}</ref>
The BCA Green Mark Scheme was launched in 2005 to promote sustainability in the built environment and raise environmental awareness among developers, designers and builders.<ref>{{cite web|title=About BCA Green Mark Scheme|url=http://www.bca.gov.sg/greenmark/green_mark_buildings.html|publisher=Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=30 November 2011}}</ref> It assesses the environmental friendliness and energy efficiency of buildings. In 2005, there were only 17 Green Mark building projects in Singapore.<ref>{{cite web|title=Factsheet on BCA Green Mark|url=http://www.bca.gov.sg/newsroom/others/pr04082011_GMESB.pdf|publisher=Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=30 November 2011}}</ref>
In 2009, BCA launched South-East Asia’s first Zero Energy Building (ZEB) located at the BCA Academy of the Built Environment. The ZEB was retrofitted from an existing building and serves as a test-bedding centre for green building technologies.<ref>{{cite news|title=$10m plan to create S'pore's first zero-energy building|date=8 November 2007|newspaper=The Straits Times}}</ref> The building is expected to be about 40-50% more efficient than an office building of similar layout.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.asiaone.com/Business/News/Story/A1Story20091026-176057.html|title=Singapore's first Zero Energy Building launched today|date=26 October 2009|newspaper=AsiaOne|accessdate=11 December 2011}}</ref>
In 2010, BCA became the first government agency outside North America to be conferred the Aspen Institute’s Energy and Environment Award (Government) for its comprehensive policies and programmes in steering development of green buildings and sustainable construction.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Aspen Institute Announces Winners and Finalists of the 2010 Aspen Institute Energy and Environment Awards. (Press release)|url=http://www.aspeninstitute.org/news/2010/07/20/aspen-institute-announces-winners-finalists-2010-aspen-institute-energy-environment-|publisher=The Aspen Institute. 20 July 2011|accessdate=9 December 2011}}</ref> In 2011, Singapore was ranked first in green building policies, before advanced cities like Tokyo, Sydney and Seoul, in a study conducted by [[Solidiance]] on Asia-Pacific cities.<ref>{{cite news|title=Asia Pacific’s Top 5 Green Cities|newspaper=The Sunday Times|date=13 February 2011}}</ref>
In December 2011, there are more than 940 green building projects, translating to a gross floor area of about 300 million ft2, or 12% of Singapore’s total gross floor area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bca.gov.sg/Newsroom/pr06122011_WGBC.html|title=International Recognition for BCA Singapore and its Green Building Masterplan. (Press release)|publisher=Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=11 December 2011}}</ref> The BCA Green Mark Scheme includes districts, parks, infrastructure, office interiors, and residential and non-residential buildings. In 2011, the Scheme was extended to include restaurants<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1152544/1/.html|title=Restaurants awarded BCA Green Mark certification|date=12 September 2011|newspaper=Channel NewsAsia|accessdate=9 December 2011}}</ref> and existing schools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bca.gov.sg/newsroom/others/pr04082011_GMES.pdf|title=New Green Mark Award for Existing Schools. (Press release)|publisher=Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=9 December 2011}}</ref> The scheme has also extended its reach beyond Singapore . More than 120 projects in countries like China, Malaysia, Vietnam, Brunei, India, Thailand, Saudi Arabia, Indonesia, The Philippines and Tanzania have applied for the Green Mark certification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bca.gov.sg/newsroom/others/pr04082011_GMESB.pdf|title=Factsheet on BCA Green Mark|publisher=Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=30 November 2011}}</ref>
BCA clinched the inaugural Regional Leadership Award, one of the six awards handed out at the World Green Building Council Government Leadership Awards 2011, for its Green Building Masterplan and leadership in the green building movement in Asia Pacific.<ref>{{cite web|title=WorldGBC Government Leadership Awards|url=http://www.worldgbc.org/site2/programs/awards/|publisher=World Green Building Council|accessdate=11 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111128001114/http://www.worldgbc.org/site2/programs/awards|archivedate=28 November 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
BCA collaborates with the [[United Nations Environment Programme]] (UNEP) to promote sustainable building practices. In 2011, BCA and UNEP finalised an agreement establishing BCA’s Centre for Sustainable Buildings as a “Centre Collaborating with UNEP”, the first in Asia. Through the collaboration, both BCA and UNEP will provide policy advice and outreach activities related to sustainable building resource management in sector in tropical cities and regions worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|title=Factsheet on UNEP-BCA MOU|url=http://www.bca.gov.sg/newsroom/others/pr12092011_IGBCA.pdf|publisher=Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=13 December 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Close to 1,000 delegates attended the International Green Building Conference 2011.JPG|thumb|Close to 1,000 delegates attended the International Green Building Conference 2011]]
BCA organised the second International Green Building Conference in September 2011 during the Singapore Green Building Week. The event attracted close to 1,000 delegates from over 32 countries, including industry experts, practitioners, and policy-makers,<ref>{{cite web|title=International Green Building Conference|url=http://www.sgbw.com.sg/|accessdate=30 December 2011}}</ref> Other green building events that BCA conducts include the roving BCA Green Building Exhibitions with green building tips and information for residents to make their homes more environmentally friendly. The annual BCA Awards recognises sustainable buildings, and honous industry professionals committed to safe, high quality and user-friendly buildings.
In 2016, BCA set up the world's first high-rise rotatable laboratory for the tropics - the BCA SkyLab. Modelled after the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory's FLEXLAB, the facility is a rotatable test facility pivotal to developing energy efficient building technologies.<ref>{{cite web|title=BCA-SkyLab|url=https://www.bca.gov.sg/skylab/|publisher=Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=3 November 2016}}</ref>
== Accessibility == In 1990, BCA introduced the Code on Barrier-Free Accessibility, reshaping the accessibility landscape of Singapore’s built environment by improving inter-connectivity between buildings and upgrading existing buildings to make them more accessible. A $40 million fund has been set aside to co-fund voluntary upgrading on basic barrier-free features over a period of five years. Additionally, BCA has legislative measures in place to ensure continued compliance to the Code and to prevent misuse of barrier-free facilities.
BCA also promotes Universal Design (UD) for buildings to cater to the needs of all users, including the young, the elderly, persons with disabilities, and parents with infants. The BCA Universal Design Award was launched in early 2007, recognising outstanding achievements by building developers and owners to incorporate barrier-free accessibility and UD in their developments.<ref>{{cite web|title=UD Awards|url=http://www.friendlybuildings.sg/web2/Contents/Contents.aspx?Id=41|publisher=Our Friendly Built Environment Portal. Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=11 December 2011}}</ref>
BCA maintains an Accessibility Rating System on its Friendly Buildings portal, which classifies buildings according to levels of user-friendliness. The system provides detailed information such as the location of accessible entrances and other accessibility facilities, to aid building users on locating accessible buildings in Singapore. By December 2011, about 3,000 buildings have been rated of which 2,200 of them are accessible.<ref>{{cite web|title=Frequently Asked Question – How many buildings have been rated?|url=http://www.friendlybuildings.sg/web/Contents/Contents.aspx?Contid=188|publisher=Our Friendly Built Environment Portal. Building and Construction Authority|accessdate=11 December 2011}}</ref>
== Training and professional standards== BCA has put in place many schemes to help raise the construction industry’s skill levels and professionalism, design and construction capabilities, niche expertise, and the export of construction-related services. Some examples are the Construction Registration of Tradesmen (CoreTrade) Scheme to establish a core base of trade foremen and tradesmen,<ref>{{cite web|title=Aesperon - What Is CoreTrade|url=http://aesperoncoretrade.com/what-is-bca-coretrade/|publisher=Aesperon - What Is CoreTrade|accessdate=1 May 2015}}</ref> and the BCA Academy of the Built Environment to develop a professional workforce and encourage the adoption of innovative technologies. BCA International, a wholly owned subsidiary formed by BCA, paves the way for local construction companies to offer a full scope of expertise and value-added services to assist overseas governments and clients in developing excellent built environments.
BCA also established a Construction Productivity Gallery and a Centre for Lean and Virtual Construction to guide and advise construction firms on the latest construction technologies and re-engineering processes to achieve time and labour savings. This is in line with Singapore’s national productivity drive, where BCA introduced a S$250-million Construction Productivity and Capability Fund (CPCF)<ref>{{cite web|title=CPCF Construction Productivity & Capability Fund Overview|url=http://aesperoncoretrade.com/bca-cpcf-fund-enhancement/|publisher=Aesperon - BCA CPCF Construction Productivity & Capability Fund|accessdate=20 May 2015}}</ref> in June 2010 to help the construction industry build up a skilled workforce, adopt more advanced construction technologies, and enhance building capability in niche areas.<ref>{{cite web|title=Transforming the Construction Industry through Capability Development and Productivity Improvement|url=http://www.mof.gov.sg/budget_2011/expenditure_overview/mnd.html|publisher=Singapore Budget 2011 – Expenditure Overview. Ministry of Finance|accessdate=30 November 2011}}</ref>
BCA strongly promotes the adoption of [[Building information modeling|Building Information Modelling]] (BIM), which allows professionals to work on a building project digitally before it is built. BCA targets to get 80 per cent of the industry to use BIM widely by 2015, and is working with the public sector to take the lead in driving greater BIM adoptiont.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bca.gov.sg/Newsroom/pr02112011_BI.html | title=Public sector has role to play in adoption of BIM, say experts | date=2 November 2011}}</ref>
